voice.core_quality: Intimate and confessional. The reader is inside the character's head, privy to thoughts they wouldn't say out loud. Vulnerability masked by wit.
voice.tone: Warm but sharp. Humor that deflects from pain. Sarcasm as armor. The jokes land but there's always something underneath.
voice.emotional_register: Big feelings treated with specificity. Not 'she was sad' but the exact texture of that sadness — what it tastes like, where it sits in the body, what memory it triggers.

sentence_rhythm.pattern: Variation is everything. Long flowing sentences for emotion and interiority. Short punchy ones for impact. Fragments for emphasis. The rhythm follows the emotional beat.
sentence_rhythm.short_sentences: Use for: gut punches, realizations, tension, humor. 'He was here. He was actually here.' or 'Well. Shit.'
sentence_rhythm.long_sentences: Use for: building atmosphere, deep POV, sensory immersion, the character spiraling in their own head.
sentence_rhythm.fragments: Use sparingly but deliberately. 'The way he looked at me. Like I was the answer to something.' Fragments create pause. Weight.

word_choice.principle: Specific beats generic. 'Coffee' is fine. 'The burnt dregs of the office Keurig' is better. Details that do double duty — reveal character while grounding scene.
word_choice.avoid: Purple prose. Flowery language. Thesaurus words that pull the reader out. If you wouldn't think the word, your character wouldn't either.
word_choice.dialogue_tags: Said is invisible. Use it. Avoid adverbs in tags — 'angrily' is lazy. Show the anger in the words or the action.

paragraph_structure.principle: White space is pacing. Short paragraphs speed things up. Longer ones slow down. A one-line paragraph is a spotlight.
paragraph_structure.interiority: Internal monologue can run long but break it up. Action, thought, action. Don't let the character spiral for three paragraphs without something happening.

pov_and_tense.default: First person, past tense. Deep POV — we're in their head completely.
pov_and_tense.dual_pov: For romance, alternate between leads. Each voice must be distinct — different cadence, different fixations, different humor.
pov_and_tense.close_third: If using third person, stay close. Limited omniscience. We know only what the POV character knows.
pov_and_tense.head_hopping: Never. One POV per scene minimum, ideally per chapter.

dialogue.principle: Dialogue is action. Every line should do at least two things — reveal character, advance plot, build tension, establish relationship dynamics.
dialogue.subtext: What's not said matters more than what is. Characters talk around the thing. They deflect. They change the subject. Real people rarely say exactly what they mean.

banter.rhythm: Quick volleys. Interruptions. Unfinished sentences. '—' is your friend.
banter.function: Banter builds intimacy while maintaining distance. It's foreplay. The joke is never just a joke.
banter.balance: Banter needs contrast. If every exchange is witty, none of them land. Earn the humor with moments of sincerity.

dialogue.tension_in_dialogue: Pauses. 'He didn't answer.' What someone doesn't say. Eye contact held too long. The moment before speaking.

avoid.exposition_dumps: No character explains things both people already know.
avoid.on_the_nose: If the reader can predict exactly what someone will say, it's too obvious.
avoid.uniform_voice: Every character should sound different. Vocabulary, rhythm, what they notice.

emotional_beats.building: Emotion needs setup. The payoff works because of what came before. Plant the wound early. Let it fester. Then press on it.
emotional_beats.earning_moments: Big emotional moments must be earned. The reader needs to want it before you give it to them. Delay gratification.
emotional_beats.the_gut_punch: Comes from specificity. Not 'she missed him' but the specific thing that triggers the missing — his coffee mug still in the cabinet, the indent on his side of the bed.
emotional_beats.aftermath: Don't skip the aftermath. The moment after the kiss. The morning after. The drive home. Quiet beats where characters process.

romantic_tension.proximity: Put them close. Physical space that feels too small. Accidental touches. Awareness of the other person's body.
romantic_tension.interruption: The almost-moment. They lean in and — someone walks in. The phone rings. They stop themselves. Delay the payoff.
romantic_tension.awareness: Hyperawareness of small details. The way they hold their glass. A new haircut. The smell of their jacket.
romantic_tension.denial: Characters who want each other but won't admit it. The lies they tell themselves. The reader knows before the character does.

scene_pacing.enter_late_leave_early: Start scenes in the middle of action. End before the conversation fully resolves.
scene_pacing.chapter_endings: End on a question, a revelation, a shift. Give the reader a reason to turn the page.
scene_pacing.chapter_openings: Hook immediately. Action, distinctive voice, a question that needs answering.

writing_heat.philosophy: Intimacy over choreography. Emotion over mechanics. What the moment means matters more than what goes where.
writing_heat.building_to_it: Sexual tension is built over chapters, not paragraphs. The first time together is the payoff of everything before.

during.stay_in_pov: Deep in the character's head. What they feel, notice, want.
during.sensory_specific: Concrete details. Not 'it felt good' but what specifically — the texture, the sound, the unexpected moment.
during.dialogue: Keep it minimal and real. What would they actually say? Probably not much. Probably not complete sentences.
during.emotion: The vulnerability of being seen. The shift in the relationship. What this means to them.

avoid.purple_prose: No 'throbbing members' or 'heaving bosoms.' Specific and grounded.
avoid.mechanical: Not a technical manual. Skip the logistics that don't serve the emotion.
avoid.out_of_character: They should sound like themselves, just... more exposed.

character_work.interiority: We need to live in their head. Their specific way of seeing the world. What they notice. What they avoid thinking about.
character_work.wounds: Every character has a wound. It informs their choices, their fears, their defenses. The romance heals or confronts that wound.
character_work.flaws: Likable doesn't mean perfect. Give them real flaws — not 'too clumsy' but actual character flaws they have to grow past.
character_work.desire_vs_need: What they want vs what they actually need. The romance reveals the gap.
character_work.growth: They should be different by the end. Changed by the relationship. Earned growth, not sudden transformation.

structure.opening: Establish voice, character, and stakes within the first chapter. The reader decides quickly whether to commit.
structure.first_act: Meet the leads. Establish their worlds, wounds, and wants. Create the circumstance that forces them together.
structure.midpoint: Something shifts. Often the first real moment of vulnerability or intimacy. Raises the stakes.
structure.dark_moment: All seems lost. Internal wounds externalized. They push each other away. The reader must believe it might not work out.
structure.resolution: Earned reconciliation. They choose each other having confronted their shit. Satisfying but not saccharine.

signature_techniques.the_callback: Plant a small detail early — a phrase, an object, a memory. Pay it off later with new meaning.
signature_techniques.the_list: Internal monologue that lists things. 'Three things I knew: 1) He was lying. 2) I was going to let him. 3) I was already lost.'
signature_techniques.the_pivot: Sentence that starts one direction and pivots. 'I was going to tell him to leave. Instead, I stepped aside.'
signature_techniques.the_mirror: Two scenes that echo each other — same setup, different outcome. Shows how things have changed.
signature_techniques.the_specificity: The weirdly specific detail that makes it real. Not 'a song on the radio' but 'that one Fleetwood Mac song my mom used to cry to.'
